DOC.brief_summary: This study compares the results of current standard coagulation measurement devices to the Quantra System, a new device, using small amount of extra blood obtained during routine blood draws in neurosurgery patients.
DOC.detailed_description: HemoSonics is developing a novel POC diagnostic device, the Quantra System, to perform whole blood coagulation analysis and which is suitable for use in surgical and intensive care settings. The Quantra System employs a patented technology named sonorheometry, which was invented at the University of Virginia. Sonorheometry uses ultrasound pulses to characterize the dynamic changes in viscoelastic properties of a blood sample during coagulation and clot lysis. The initial assay performed on the Quantra System will be the surgical assay for monitoring hemostasis during major surgical procedures in adult patients. A clinical study will be conducted to evaluate the analytical performance as well as compared to existing coagulation monitoring technology
DOC.criteria: • Subject is scheduled for major deformity correction spine surgery Subject is older than 18 years Subject is willing to participate and he/she has signed a consent form • Subject is unable to provide written informed consent Subject is incarcerated at the time of the study Subject is affected by any condition that, in the opinion of the surgical team, may pose additional risks Subjects with renal disease (defined as serum creatinine greater than 1.5 mg/dl) Subjects with history of active liver disease Subjects affected by Factor V Leiden mutation Subjects affected by von Willebrand disease Subjects with an history of thrombotic disease (more than one DVT)
